title: 110_hr3357
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. The Congress finds that the United States is facing a crisis in writing skills in schools and the workplace, with nearly 1/3 of high school graduates not ready for college-level English composition. Deficiencies in writing skills result in high private-sector costs for training, and writing is a key skill for employment and promotion. The National Writing Project has been the only national program addressing this issue since 1973. The National Writing Project has shown significant gains in student writing performance and effective classroom practices. It serves as a model for programs in various fields and benefits over 135,000 teachers annually in nearly 200 sites across the US. The National Writing Project, under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, aims to expand its network of sites nationwide, ensure high-quality programs, disseminate effective teaching practices, and coordinate activities with the Act. The National Writing Project, established under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, focuses on expanding its network of sites nationwide, ensuring high-quality programs, sharing effective teaching practices, and coordinating activities with the Act. The Secretary is authorized to award a grant to the National Writing Project, a nonprofit organization focused on improving student writing and learning. The grant requires the organization to work with educational providers to enhance teacher training programs in effective writing approaches. The National Writing Project is awarded a grant by the Secretary to improve writing teaching processes. The funds will be used for teacher training programs for grades kindergarten through college, conducted during the school year and summer months. The grantee must meet conditions set by the Secretary for compliance. The National Writing Project is awarded a grant by the Secretary to improve writing teaching processes. The grant will fund teacher training programs for grades kindergarten through college, with a Federal share of 50% of the costs to the contractor. Teachers will be selected to join a National Writing Project teacher network to conduct writing workshops for other teachers. The National Writing Project will establish a National Advisory Board composed of national educational leaders and writing experts to oversee teacher training programs with a maximum Federal share of $150,000 per contractor. The National Writing Project will establish a National Advisory Board to advise on student writing issues, review programs, and support development. The Secretary will conduct an independent evaluation of teacher training programs funded by the project. The National Writing Project will establish a National Review Board consisting of leaders in writing research to evaluate teacher training programs. The Secretary will reserve funds for this evaluation for fiscal years 2008 and beyond. The National Writing Project will establish a National Review Board to review and recommend applications for funding. $30,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008 and subsequent years.
